9.text:
My name is Dharmash Patel and I'm an actor.
And you were born in the UK?

14.text:
I was born in the UK. I was raised in London.
Er, well I was born in Kettering, raised in

18.text:
London, er, went to, moved to Harrow when
I was about twelve, and then went to uni in

24.text:
Liverpool. And then travelled round ever since,
really, like a hobo. (laughs)

29.text:
And you feel London is your home?
London, London is, yeah, without a shadow

35.text:
of a doubt, em... It's funny, because whenever
you go across the world, people always say

40.text:
where are you from, and I always find myself
saying I'm from London. I never say I'm from

45.text:
England, and it's strange because when you
come back to London, you feel like you're

52.text:
home. It it it's a strange concept I know.
I know it sounds bizzare. We've all got our

58.text:
home towns and I think that's what the world
is becoming now. It's not becoming about what

63.text:
country are you from. I think it's about what
what place you're from and what that does

67.text:
to you. Em, because I don't know what it is
to be English. I know what it is to be someone

74.text:
from London. Em, I know the people of London.
Er, people in Britain. They are so, they are

81.text:
so versatile, they are so diverse, you know,
that there isn't just one type of person and

85.text:
I think that's what London is for me it's
a caco, like a cacophony of colours and cultures

92.text:
and music and art and theatre and football.
Football is very important to me. (laughs)

101.text:
Em, so yeah, London is home. Yeah.
And how do you define home?

107.text:
Do you know, I know when I'm home when my
shoulders drop. When I'm in London, I feel

117.text:
my shoulders drop. The moment I get on the
train, the Underground, and I know it sounds

122.text:
strange, but, you relax into a pace, and it's
very fast, it's very energetic, but there's

128.text:
also a serenity to it. There's also a feel.
It's hard to explain the feeling. It's hard

136.text:
to explain something that you can't, that
you can't explain. It's just something you

142.text:
know, you know. Yeah.
So let's talk about the journey you've taken

147.text:
in your life then because you obviously have
to start from a place and a home is a very

152.text:
good place to start from.
Yeah. (laughs) Always a great place.

155.text:
So how do you see your artistic journey?
Em...till now? I I think my artistic journey

166.text:
began as a kid. Em, it was a lot of, I grew
up in a, my parents are immigrants. They came

175.text:
with £26 and nothing else. And you quickly
realize you don't have toys to play with.

180.text:
You don't have anything but your imagination.
And I had three older sisters. I never had

184.text:
brothers, but we had loads of animals in the
house. So I'd go on these little adventures

188.text:
with the dog that I used to have. And I know
that sounds bizarre but when you don't have

194.text:
anything, any materialistic stuff what you
quickly find is that your imagination becomes

200.text:
your, your playground. And that, for me was.
When I kind of thought, looking back, I kind

209.text:
of go yeah, that's where, that's where it
began. As a kid, growing up with not very

214.text:
much. Having to make my own fun and...and
not having many friends because you are the

218.text:
only hindu person in Whitechapel because it
was a predominantly Bangladeshi community

224.text:
and there was my one black friend, Clifton,
and we used to get into a lot of fights as

228.text:
kids 'cause we were, we were the outcasts
in that community. Em, and so we we would

233.text:
have our own adventures and stuff. And my
parents had a shop, you know. So we were well

237.text:
known in the community. Em...I've gone off
track. What was the question?

243.text:
That's absolutely great because that's the
journey isn't it?

246.text:
Yes. So that's where it began I think. That's
where my journey began. Em, playing with Clifton.

251.text:
Em, going to the park with the dog and going
on adventures. Em, and my sister, well, she

260.text:
was always into dance. She was into kathak
dance and she's still is, she still does it.

264.text:
And she would dress me up, and, you know,
she would make me do dance and would watch,

268.text:
em, like Bollywood films, classic Bollywood
films, black and white films, and there was

274.text:
a lot of singing and dancing in that. So I
was always surrounded by it. Always, always.

278.text:
Em, but I don't think I was ever conscious
of it. It, for me, it was just part of my

284.text:
upbringing. And when I went to school, I...I
had a brilliant drama teacher who invited

293.text:
me into this world of theatre, who, I think
she gave me the bug for it. Em, but I knew

300.text:
I could never do it 'cause it was never an
option, you know. It was never something I'd

304.text:
take seriously. I still don't take it very
seriously, because, it's a bizarre concept

310.text:
to be paid to do what you love in this world,
isn't it. It is. Er, think of this seven billion

317.text:
people on this planet and how many of those
people actually get to do what they love.

321.text:
And you quickly realize that you're actually
in a very privileged position. But not when

326.text:
you are younger. I think it comes with age,
and that sounds condescending, but it's, because

330.text:
people said it to me when I was growing up,
but it's true. With age I think you begin

334.text:
to realize what's important and what you want
to do with your career. And then you meet

338.text:
other people along the way. Em, I went to
a place called, er em, Hope Street, in Liverpool,

345.text:
which was a physical theatre school and that,
that one...that one thing molded me into who

353.text:
I am today. Because I met the likes of Paul
Hunter and Madani Younis and Improbable and

359.text:
Complicite and people like that who made theatre
more than what we know it. What I knew of

366.text:
it at the time. Very bland, very sort of simplistic.
Nothing very exciting. And when you meet those

374.text:
people, you quickly realize of what you want
to achieve with your career and the people

380.text:
you want to admire and the people you want
to, to look up to. And when you realise that,

386.text:
I think you begin to think about the work
that you want to do. And the influences that

391.text:
they have had over your work. And so you quickly
forget about the colour of your skin. For

396.text:
me, it was very much about that. It's was
forgetting about who I am or where I'm from,

401.text:
although that will always stay with me. I
think, the older I get, the more decisions

405.text:
I get to make for myself, and I choose not
to be a colour. I choose not be a face for

415.text:
a type of theatre. I choose not to be type
cast, I hope. Because if you look at the likes

423.text:
of Paul Hunter and he will always have a magnificent
affect on my career, you quickly realize,

430.text:
nothing can stop you, as long as your imagination
is still working. As long as you're still

435.text:
presenting work which excites you, and which
you want to explore and you want to share.

440.text:
Em, and he does everything. He writes, he
directs, em, he's a performer. Phenomenal

447.text:
performer. Phenomenal director, and, a brilliant
improviser. Him and Hayley Carmichael who

454.text:
have Told By An Idiot. And you quickly realize
those are the people I want to be like when

458.text:
I grow up. (laughs) When I grow up, I want
to be like them. That's my journey yah.

465.text:
And it's great that you have this, you don'
have a problem being South Asian as such,

471.text:
because I think the older generation did encounter
that. They found that they did not have the

475.text:
opportunities that perhaps you do now, coming
from London and how it's developed as a community.

483.text:
Yeah, of course.
Which is I suppose the reason why you say

488.text:
it's home.
Yeah, of course. But I think there are so

492.text:
many influences in your life aren't there.
Your parents. What I what I realize. I didn't

497.text:
realize at the time. Of course my parents
had a problem with me wanting to be an actor.

501.text:
Of course they did. Because who in their right
mind turns around to their parents and goes,

506.text:
I'm I'm going to be an actor. I'll be brilliant.
I'll make some money and will, I'll look after

510.text:
you, It'll be it'll be great. My dad's first
reaction was, are you stupid. And my reaction

516.text:
was yes, I I think I am. It's alright. But
it takes time, doesn't, with parents. Like

522.text:
everything else. It's relationship you you're
constantly building on. It's like a relationship

528.text:
with a partner. If you don't grow together,
you're not, you are going to grow apart. And

532.text:
that's exactly what it is with my parents.
We've, my career's grown with them and they've

538.text:
learnt to accept the fact that I can make
a living from being an actor. Not, full time.

546.text:
'Cause, let's face it, unless you are a superstar,
you are not going to make a a living from

552.text:
it. But I I do OK, and I'm inspired by the
by the people I work with. And there's nothing

558.text:
better than wake up in the morning and go,
I get to go to work today and do what I love.

564.text:
And. I think, the older I got, I quickly realized
that, my parents didn't have a problem with

570.text:
me being an actor. What they had a problem
with was making sure they did the absolute

575.text:
best for me growing up, and gave me the best
opportunities. We moved from Whitechapel to

581.text:
Harrow when I was twelve, because, they knew
that if they stayed in Whitechapel I was going

587.text:
to get in trouble. And I was starting to get
in trouble, em, and we moved to Harrow. And

591.text:
they took me to a better school. And I was
influenced by those people. Em, I'm not saying

597.text:
everyone that grows up in Whitechapel turns
out to be a bad egg. It's not true. It's just

601.text:
that I had nothing better to do with my time.
I wasn't around people that could influence

607.text:
my life. Em, yeah, parents are a funny thing.
Em, they they just want the best for you I

614.text:
guess, bt yeah.
So the question of influences is really important

618.text:
isn't it. Because you are talking about influences
that are quite universal in your own career

625.text:
now as opposed to quite community ethnic,
you know, that that sort of influence. So,

633.text:
do you still have an association through your
work, with the South Asian community. Like

639.text:
for example, this play that you are working
on.

642.text:
Yes. Well ay the moment, we are working on
a play based on the South Asian gay community

647.text:
and we're asking a question of what is their
voice and how can we, how can we hear their

652.text:
voice. For me, it doesn't matter what the
what the identity of the company is. What

660.text:
matters to me is the content. So you could
say that I've done four projects which was

668.text:
classify as South Asian. Er one of them was
pretty much after the 7/7 bombings with Rasa

674.text:
and we worked on a production where about
a young, a family, a family who encounter

683.text:
a, whose youngest son, whose oldest son is
a, an Imam, and the youngest son is caught

690.text:
up in this radical, the radical views. It's
an interesting story because it tells the

696.text:
story of the family, em, and where they are,
at that state in time when we face the 7/7

703.text:
bombings. The second project I worked on was
with Many Younis, em, was about a young boy

709.text:
dying in police custody and what affect that
has on the family. And also the fact that,

715.text:
at the time, not not a single policeman had
been convicted of death death in custody since

721.text:
the 60s. That was for me a fascinating subject.
The 7/7 was a fascinating subject. Em, I worked

729.text:
with Kali, er, on Tagore's women, and for
me, Tagore's women is a fascinating subject,

735.text:
Er, well Tagore is a, I mean, he is someone
we all admire, er, from South Asian community,

744.text:
because he was ahead of his time. He was the
one that advocated women's rights and voices.

750.text:
He, he was a lothario wasn't he slept with
many women. He wrote beautiful poetry. He

757.text:
was well educated. He didn't come from a,
from a hard background. He was, he came from

763.text:
an affluent background. But still a magical
man. Em, yeah. This, and of course this project

773.text:
which is again voicing the voices which we
don't really hear in South Asian communities.

780.text:
And so for me it's not about the, the, where
the company is from. It's more about the project

789.text:
that we do. In ten years, it must say a lot
for a young performer, whose only done four

796.text:
projects, er, with what we identify as South
Asian theatre companies. Because, yeah, because

804.text:
I don't feel I can identify with them. What
I can identify with is the content. The project,

811.text:
the project's content. Like the 7/7 bombings
in my beautiful city. Like someone dying in

817.text:
police custody and no one being responsible
for it and how that affects a family. Em,

824.text:
Tagore, someone that you grow up with admiring,
and the gay community, which doesn't have

830.text:
a voice in our own what we describe as South
Asian community. So those are interesting

836.text:
subjects for me.
And em, would you consider that the em, label

842.text:
like South Asian theatre is useful or not
useful?

847.text:
I think, do you know, I was thinking about
this, and I've been thinking about this for

852.text:
a long time, and I think for me, as time's
gone on, I've, to begin with, I'd never accepted

858.text:
it. I hated it. I hated the, the notion of
it. Because it pigeon holes you. It turns

864.text:
you into something you may not be. Er cultural
experiences you may not have experienced,

871.text:
er, because it's all identified based on the
colour of your skin. Now. For me, essentially,

878.text:
that's racism, at it's basic level, isn't
it. You're you're judging someone and their

883.text:
experiences based on the colour of your skin.
And I don't identify with those stories that

891.text:
are told in those South Asian communities.
I had a very different upbringing. Em, we

898.text:
were very family orientatated. We were very
close, you know. We we grew up in Whitechapel.

905.text:
We had dogs. We, we lived above a shop, you
know. So in some ways you could say it's a

910.text:
typical existence, but fundamentally, we're
human beings aren't we. We experience the

917.text:
same thing that someone ten thousand miles
away is facing at this very same moment who

923.text:
does have a shop, who isn't the same colour
of my skin, who has children who lives above

927.text:
their shop, who find, whose probably an immigrant,
you know. Their their constant, I just have

935.text:
a human story. I don't have an ethnic story.
I I find that hard to comprehend because,

945.text:
by labeling, what we do is we stop are society
from moving on. We we, we stop ourselves from

952.text:
evolving. Em, em and that's what I love about
London. It's a community. It's, when the 7/7

960.text:
bombings happened, we as a community rallied
together and it was, it was a magnificent

964.text:
sight. I can't stop looking outside your window
'cause it's my city. It's the noises that

970.text:
I love, and, so it reminds me, yeah. I don't
think it is helpful.

976.text:
So, do you think there's a kind of transnationalism
that actually informs your identity.

984.text:
Yeah, of course. You can't. I can't forget,
I can't forget my heritage. I can't 'cause

991.text:
it's part of me. It's part of who I am and
it's part of what I've grown up in. There

998.text:
there's that brilliant phrase isn't there,
the coconut, which, yeah, I I think it does

1002.text:
describe me. I'm I'm I'm happy to say that.
And it's something we talk we talk about in

1007.text:
the play at the moment. And I don't think
there's anything wrong with being a coconut,

1012.text:
because actually, what you're open to, is
cultures. What you're open to are stories

1020.text:
outside of your own community. Community,
I use that in a very loose sense because what

1027.text:
community is for me it may something very
different for someone else. Em...but my, my

1037.text:
Indian and African heritage has absolutely
informed who I am and what I want to do and

1043.text:
I know a lot about my heritage. And what's
upsetting is when people who are in South

1050.text:
Asian theatre tell me I don't know about my
roots. And it's happened to me a few times

1058.text:
and I think it's brilliant in a sense because
what you could be, realize is, these people

1066.text:
have a very simplistic view of what it is
to be Asian. They go based on the colour of

1073.text:
their skin and what the stereotypes are, and
actually, they are not those people that are

1077.text:
branching out into the world. I went to Namibia
for like three weeks and I felt just at home

1084.text:
there because, it, it is a magnificent place.
It's vast lands of roaming animals and these

1095.text:
kind of, these really beautiful tribes which
still exist and these beautiful, this beautiful

1104.text:
history, em, of the Germans you know, coming
in and they still speak German in Namibia

1109.text:
and the four clicks which you have to learn
for the language. They still have the same

1116.text:
universal problems that I have. And...I think
that's what I find really difficult. I find

1127.text:
that really difficult that first and foremost,
what I'm branded with is the colour of my

1133.text:
skin and not the fact that I can, it's this,
I know this is going to sound really, I try

1143.text:
not to swear, er, this is going to sound really
pathetic in a sense, but I', really heavily

1148.text:
influenced by Shakespeare, especially at the
moment, and there's a brilliant monologue

1154.text:
by Shylock in Merchant of Venice. 'If you
prick me, do I not bleed?' And, it's true

1159.text:
isn't it. The same problem has been occurring
for six hundred, a thousand , two thousand,

1166.text:
ten thousand years, And as human beings, we
still not have, we still haven't learnt the

1171.text:
fact that we're causing the same problem and
not moving on. 'If you prick me, do I not

1178.text:
bleed?' Hell yeah, I'm going to bleed 'cause
I'm a human being as much as you are, do you

1182.text:
know what I mean? We bleed the same colour.
I find it really odd. I find it really odd

1188.text:
that we are still living in a society where
we are still trying to pigeon hole each other

1197.text:
and it's, it's depressing and which is why,
I think, in a sense, I've stopped caring about

1203.text:
it. When I was younger, I was really angry
about it. And the older I get, I quickly realized

1210.text:
that, the people I want to be like aren't
Asian, in the South Asian community, there

1217.text:
there's maybe one or two who I admire, but
in what we know as British theatre, not white

1224.text:
theatre, British theatre, the likes of Paul
Hunter, Hayley Carmichael, em, the theatre

1230.text:
companies like Improbable, like Complicite,
the people like Madani Younis who are trying

1236.text:
to be more than just, they just want to be
artists. They just want to, they want to work,

1245.text:
and they want to do good work, and they, solid
work. They they work on a very simple foundation,

1251.text:
that we will try and produce the best things.
And I guarantee you, if you go and see one

1255.text:
of their shows and you've never been to the
theatre before, you'll want to go again. Whereas,

1261.text:
if you go and see bad theatre, and I'm not
saying South Asian theatre is bad. I'm saying

1267.text:
any type of theatre, If you see a bad production,
you'll not wanna go to the theatre again.

1272.text:
Period. Because your first influence is, well
your first impressions are they last. And

1281.text:
that's what I love about them.
So all this, your thoughts and philosophies,

1287.text:
what kind of audiences would you like to communicate
these too because, obviously, you are a communicator.

1294.text:
Yeah. Em... (laughs) you are a communicator.
That wasn't very good communication was it.

1300.text:
I I don't believe that there's, that there
is a type of audience, personally. I think

1308.text:
the work that I hopefully do and want to do
and the productions I want to be a part of.

1314.text:
Is open for anyone. I like to think the story
that I will tell the company of actors that

1319.text:
I work with, would be universal. It won't
matter whether I'm Asian or, or any other...colour.

1333.text:
What matters is the stories that we tell are
universal and you can identify with the person

1341.text:
on stage. Not because of the colour of their
skin but because of the words that are coming

1347.text:
out of their mouths. That the emotions that
that individual is going through, the journey

1352.text:
that they are going through in in front of
your eyes. And that's what theatre is for

1358.text:
me. It's taking an audience on a journey.
On spectacular journey, whether they laugh

1365.text:
or cry or walk out.
You were saying to me earlier that you write

1370.text:
your own stuff which you perform for yourself
only. So...

1372.text:
(laughs) I don't perform it.
Oh, you don't perform it.

1374.text:
I don't write my own stuff and then sit at
home in front of the mirror, ah, that's very

1380.text:
good. No, yah.
So how important is an audience to you.

1385.text:
I think audiences are very important. Em,
fundamentally, if if if we just break down

1392.text:
what an audience does, fundamentally, an audience
will pay my wage. That's the very basic. There's

1398.text:
no point lying about that, because, let's
face it, theatre wouldn't exist in this country

1404.text:
if we didn't have audiences. We need an audience
to watch. Er, those are two very basic things,

1411.text:
for three, for theatre to be created, you
just need an audience there. You don't need

1414.text:
to be paid. But if you want to eat, sleep
and keep warm, then you are hoping for some

1420.text:
payment. I'm, I could be wrong, er, and for
anyone that disagrees and just wants to do

1425.text:
it for free go ahead. When you are freezing,
I'll take you in, but ultimately, we, it's

1431.text:
our job isn't it. We've chosen a profession
and we want to be paid 'cause we are passionate

1435.text:
about what we do. And I want to eat, because
I like to eat, do you know what I mean? Em...

1446.text:
But your audience, if it isn't for them, who
is it for? You, you know, you said that I

1456.text:
write my own stuff and I perform it myself,
I don't perform it, but what that does is,

1461.text:
give me an idea of where I am in my life and
it gives me an idea, so it's like a diary

1466.text:
almost. And I create characters and things
that I may use in other productions. Em and

1472.text:
it just helps your mind to tick over. And,
there's something very, writing for me is

1481.text:
is more about my own personal, er, thoughts.
It's not about wanting to share it. If I wanted

1489.text:
to write something to share with people I
would do it. But this, I kind of use it more

1492.text:
as my own diary. Em, I always write in the
third person. Em, and I've written two one

1499.text:
man shows which one was done in Edinburgh.
But it was very dark and it was it was about

1505.text:
a cannibal. Now, I can't imagine approaching
a South Asian theatre company and and saying,

1514.text:
I have a one man show about a cannibal. Do
you fancy putting it on? 'Cause the truth

1519.text:
is, I don't think they would take me seriously.
It's not the kind of thing I think they want

1525.text:
to see. Er, whereas, I think if I approach
someone like Madani and people like that,

1531.text:
they, there's a chance that he would, well,
I mean he has in the past given me a week's

1536.text:
research and development, which we did in
Bradford, and, work then got busy so I couldn't

1542.text:
go back to it. But I's about engaging our
audiences because sometimes it feels like

1549.text:
we've got a set audience, but what we are
not thinking about is the audience of the

1555.text:
future. The audience that are going to be
going to a theatre in ten years time, and

1561.text:
how do we access them. Do we start at a younger
age? Do we start influencing audiences, do

1567.text:
we start taking work into schools, and then
what type of work do we take into schools.

1571.text:
And then you ask the question of, who is the
cast? Who, what are the colours that we are

1576.text:
gonna put into this palette and rep, to present
our work. Because we need to see those, those

1585.text:
representations. We need to see a cacophony
of colours. Like we do in London. Like we

1589.text:
do in Manchester. Like we do in Liverpool,
in Birmingham. Like we do across the world.

1594.text:
It's not just one colour that we live with,
is it. It's a range.

1600.text:
So would you say the older notion of South
Asian identity is evolving into South Asian

1608.text:
non-identity.
No. I think it's a difficult one, because

1613.text:
what my parents went through, I will never
have to go through. The opportunities that

1617.text:
my parents had, er, I will never have to go
through because they gave me different opportunities.

1624.text:
The racism that they faced, I di face racism,
but not to the extent of my parents' generation

1630.text:
and my grandparents' generation and, my great
great grandparents' generation. What we have

1637.text:
to remember is we are an involving society.
We constantly are evolving. But if we are

1643.text:
not evolving in what we show in, if we are
not telling the stories of the community,

1651.text:
then surely we're, we're just staying in one
place. Which is safe. Yah. I suppose that's

1659.text:
the thing. We are staying in a safe place.
We are not challenging our audiences. What

1664.text:
are we doing? We are just presenting safe
work. And I don't think I want to be part

1670.text:
of just safe work. I think I want to be challenged
as a performer. I don't wanna be rich or famous

1678.text:
I wanna be damn good at what I do. And the
only way I can do that is by working with

1684.text:
people that are gonna help me improve and
that are going to challenge me as a performer

1689.text:
and that will ask me questions that I can
ask back. And I don't, for me that's not really

1695.text:
available in South Asian work.
Er it's interesting because we are coming

1703.text:
part of, more and more a part of a shared
community. And so, therefore, for me, South

1710.text:
Asian is almost redundant in a shared community
environment.

1715.text:
OK.
So how do we, how do you...I mean, personally

1722.text:
I think you get a lot of pressures from outside
more than from within. And these pressure

1727.text:
from outside actually can have a very negative
effect. It's up to you to find a positive

1736.text:
out of that. So I'd be quite interested to
see, to hear how, you actually find the positive.

1744.text:
Em, I think I found it by just not caring
anymore. Em, if I'm honest, em, I did a play

1754.text:
which I'm not going to tell you which one,
em, which made be realize that I have a choice

1759.text:
in the work that I do, When a good production
comes up and I get an audition for it, I will

1766.text:
try my hardest regardless of whether it's
a South Asian play or not. If it's a good

1772.text:
project, I think I wanna try and be apart
of it if I can. Em, it's essentially, when

1784.text:
I look to those people like Paul Hunter, and
I'll I'll always come back to Paul Hunter

1788.text:
and Hayley Carmichael, because when I look
at them I go, every bit of work that they

1793.text:
do they put their heart and soul into it and
what they want to do is essentially is make

1799.text:
the best work that they could possibly make.
And isn't that a brilliant philosophy to live

1805.text:
by. I just wanna make good work. I don't I
just want to make good work. I want to be

1815.text:
pushed to my limits as a performer. I want
to be challenged by the people I work with.

1820.text:
I want to know that the stories we are telling
are universal. I want to know that the people

1826.text:
that come to see the show are a representation
of the society that I live in. Em, it's really

1835.text:
simple when you are not angry about something,
because I think when you are angry, like I

1840.text:
used to be growing up, when I was a young
performer, still am young, er (laughs) when

1846.text:
I was younger performer, em, you become very
bitter about theatre and what it is and you

1856.text:
begin to loath what you do and I'm tired of,
I'm tired. I'm really tired of it. I simply

1866.text:
want to look up to those people that I look
up to, and do the best work that I can do

1875.text:
and not have to feel embarrassed when I go
on stage. And whether you like it or not,

1886.text:
that, that's my choice. You can't tell me
what to do. You can't tell me the type of

1892.text:
work I want to do. Because I'm influenced
in different ways. So it goes back to your

1898.text:
thing of, is South Asian theatre community
redundant. Well is, is any community redundant,

1909.text:
because they still have a voice, and they
still want to share something they want to

1913.text:
do. And that's fine. Just don't tell me I
don't know my roots and don't tell me that

1920.text:
I don't know where I come from. And don't
tell me that the work I do makes me a coconut

1928.text:
because the work that I do I'm very proud
of. I am very proud to be influenced by the

1933.text:
people that I'm influenced by. I'm very proud
of my CV. 'Cause I've worked hard for it.

1939.text:
I've worked so damn hard for what I've done,
and I refuse to be pinned down to a colour

1946.text:
or a community. I know I know where I'm from.
And I know what, where I exist in this cycle.

1953.text:
We're going to die one day, so, I'm enjoying
my life for what it is I'm not bogged down

1962.text:
anymore by those questions We live in a multicultural
society where people can be what they want

1971.text:
and who they want. So. I don't think it is
redundant. I don't think any community is

1978.text:
redundant. Because every community has a voice,
and I think that's what I forgot when I was

1983.text:
younger and I think it's what you learn when
you get older. And when you are influenced

1988.text:
by other people. That work is readily available
to those people that like it. My question

1995.text:
is, are you, are you communicating to that
audience that you're wanting to reach. If

2005.text:
we are specifically talking about South Asian
audiences. Are you reaching the audience that

2009.text:
you think you want to reach? And, what type
of stories are you telling? Em, are you doing,

2019.text:
are you challenging your audiences are you
offering them a new concepts? Are you helping

2024.text:
the young performers who want to go to that
area of work? Young writers? Young directors?

2030.text:
Excuse me, because, at the moment there seems
to be a stalemate where where you still have

2040.text:
the same directors for the last ten, fifteen,
twenty years, doing the same, similar sort

2045.text:
of work. It would be interesting if they mentored
younger directors that want to go into that

2051.text:
sort of work, who may be actually, rather
than tap into a South Asian community, maybe

2059.text:
tap into the British South Asian community,
which is very different. The plays that my

2064.text:
parents watch are not the plays that I watch.
We're, we're are generation apart. Now, the

2071.text:
problem occurs, when, this generation, my
parents' generation die out, because they

2077.text:
will die out, there will be a time when they
have to pass this world, as I will. Now, if

2084.text:
there is not an audience to follow them, if
there isn't an audience to watch that work,

2090.text:
then where is the theatre? What does it become?
And does it then become time, does it then

2100.text:
become time to evolve? Or, is it time to evolve
now? Because those people that are making

2107.text:
those bits of theatre, who, like me, started
with the right intentions of wanting to maybe

2114.text:
change things in theatre or wanting to voice
an opinion, we can't forget the founding work

2119.text:
that they've done the very foundation of what
they played, laid down for the likes of myself

2124.text:
to become an Asian actor, I hate using that
term, but it's, it's what I'm known as isn't

2129.text:
it, in the business that we're in. I'll always
be known as an Asian actor. But that's up

2137.text:
to people to decide. I'm a human being. But
my question still remains. When that generation

2143.text:
dies out, and you haven't got that younger
audience coming in, because, they can't really

2153.text:
identify with what's going on twenty years
ago, then what happens to South Asian theatre?

2162.text:
What des it become? Will you then decide then,
in ten years time, when those audiences begin

2167.text:
to filter away that it's now time to tap into
a younger audience where you start doing panic

2174.text:
stuff, where you haven't thought about the
things you're gonna do, you just put on a

2178.text:
production that may bring in a younger crowd?
It's is an interesting question I think, and

2184.text:
it's a question I'd like to ask those people.
It's a questions I'd like to ask the, the

2190.text:
Arts Council because, let's face it, the Arts
Council have a choice on who they fund. They,

2196.text:
they are essentially the government to the
theatre. And sometimes what happens is it's

2201.text:
very much like a, like our government. The
government will come in. They don't have a

2207.text:
clue about the communities and the societies
that they are working for, representing, but

2214.text:
what they do have is an old concept. I'm not
saying it's outdated at all, because there

2222.text:
are those generations of people that still
believe in that concept. But what happens

2227.text:
when the young try to voice an opinion. Like
the riots across England. What simply happens

2235.text:
is we are shut down, very quickly. Without
a voice and you're told that you are a troublemaker.

2244.text:
Which is what I experienced I think. I was
very much seen as a troublemaker. It wasn't

2250.text:
that I was causing trouble. I was just simply
asking the questions of my peers, and of the

2257.text:
people I was meant to look up to, who couldn't
answer me those questions. So you move on

2262.text:
to other people, don't you. You start looking
to other people to look up to and I found

2266.text:
those people. And you know the answers, by
making good theatre. With a very human, basic

2273.text:
human story. Like Shakespeare, which is universal.
Which doesn't matter what colour you are.

2283.text:
I was going to say well, apart from Othello,
because, apparently that's a, you know, 'cause

2291.text:
I am sure someone would have picked that out
and gone, well actually, er...Shakespeare's

2296.text:
universal. And that changed my opinion. When
I worked for the Shakespeare company, they,

2303.text:
Alison Bomber, who is another influence in
my life, she was a voice teacher who I met,

2308.text:
and I never went to drama school, so she taught
me so much, but what she absolutely taught

2311.text:
me was, it doesn't matter about the colour
of your skin. What it matters is, because

2316.text:
I always had a problem with it. What it matters
is you are telling a very human story. And

2321.text:
what you are doing is you're engaging with
the community of audience, of audiences. We

2328.text:
would take productions to school where it
would be a vast range of colours 'cause I

2334.text:
know colour's a big thing in theatres at the
moment. And what you, what we did do was we

2340.text:
engaged with young people at a younger age,
with a multicultural company, who are, whether

2348.text:
whether you like it or not, who are the future
audiences that will pay to go to a theatre,

2354.text:
because let's face it, if you want to do free
theatre, that's fine. I hate this notion that

2362.text:
we should do something for free because, we
work so hard, you know, and we work, we work

2373.text:
long hours. We put our hearts and souls into
something. And why shouldn't shouldn't you

2379.text:
get something back from that. I think I'm
trying to, I sound like I'm defending myself,

2384.text:
but I am. I am defending myself, But it's
the younger audiences we need to engage with

2391.text:
and if you are just engaging with a colour,
when that colour disappears, which slowly

2399.text:
it is, because I know a lot of Asian people
with partners that are not Asian, so their

2405.text:
children are not going to be the colour of
my skin. Those audiences are disappearing

2411.text:
and very quickly what happens, what happens
when those audiences no longer remain, and

2418.text:
what happens when they become tired of stories
that were told twenty years ago, what we can't

2422.text:
forget is the founding fathers of what we
know is South Asian theatre. And I never thought

2430.text:
I'd say this, but it's true. They did so much
for us. But like every government, you have

2437.text:
to ask the question how, like every company,
every corporate company, we've now, we are

2443.text:
now in the market. How do we evolve. How do
we become better than we were teo years ago,

2449.text:
five years ago, ten years ago. And the idea
of concept as well is, for me, the reason

2456.text:
South Asian theatre doesn't work is, whenever
a classic play is done, we do a classic thing

2461.text:
of setting it in the classic land of Asia.
There's there's there's no... So what we do

2470.text:
is we, we give vibrant colours to a stage
and we put a statue of Kali and we have these

2478.text:
cod Asian accents 'cause let's face it, if
you heard my Asian accent, you would think

2484.text:
I was an idiot. It's not that bad, but, but
you know, they are cod because friends from

2489.text:
India do come over, and when I hear their
accent, they're so crisp and they're so different.

2496.text:
And you look at India now, I'm just using
this as an example, as a society, and the

2501.text:
last, let's say the last year alone. How much
it has evolved in terms of women's rights,

2506.text:
in terms of, em, the rape cases that have
now come...become huge in the media, the fact

2516.text:
that those men will be hung. A year ago that
would never have happened. India is growing

2524.text:
at such a rate, we can't keep up with it.
It is. And it's becoming a well developed

2531.text:
country. What we do in Britain is we still
think it is, stuck in the Raj. And isn't it

2542.text:
funny that we are known as the more developed
race, in Britain. We've developed more than

2550.text:
the third world countries. We know so much
more. Yet that country is developing at a

2555.text:
rate that we cannot keep up with. And our,
our theatre doesn't communicate that anymore.

2565.text:
But then you, I suppose then you have to ask
the question of, are the audiences ready for

2569.text:
it. Because em, you look at the play that
was done in Birmingham about the, the women

2576.text:
that were raped in the Gurdwaras and the community
came out and they were they were in uproar,

2581.text:
and they had to stop the production. That
was ten years ago. What happens now if we

2588.text:
did the same production. Are we ready for
it as an audience. And I think the answer

2594.text:
is yes. Because of what's happened in India.
It will be interesting to see what, if that

2602.text:
play was brought back, what the reactions
would be. Are the men still afraid of...telling

2609.text:
the rest of the world what's going on in those
places, and are the women brave enough to

2614.text:
stand up, or, well they are 'cause India's
showing it. Women in millions are coming out

2620.text:
and marching and demonstrating and, they are
becoming powerful figures. My question is,

2628.text:
does South Asian theatre represent that in
today's theatre. It's a question. I don't

2636.text:
know the answer. Em, it may do. It may not.
But it's an interesting question.

2642.text:
Thank you, for ending with a question like
that.

2647.text:
No, not at all. I feel I spoke a lot.
You have.
